title: Dynamic Data Exchange
descrption: Windows Dynamic Data Exchange (DDE) is a client-server protocol for one-time and/or continuous inter-process communication (IPC) between applications. Once a link is established, applications can autonomously exchange transactions consisting of strings, warm data links (notifications when a data item changes), hot data links (duplications of changes to a data item), and requests for command execution.Object Linking and Embedding (OLE), or the ability to link data between documents, was originally implemented through DDE. Despite being superseded by COM, DDE may be enabled in Windows 10 and most of Microsoft Office 2016 via Registry keys. [1] [2] [3]Adversaries may use DDE to execute arbitrary commands. Microsoft Office documents can be poisoned with DDE commands [4] [5], directly or through embedded files [6], and used to deliver execution via phishing campaigns or hosted Web content, avoiding the use of Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) macros. [7] DDE could also be leveraged by an adversary operating on a compromised machine who does not have direct access to command line execution.
Data Sources: API monitoring, DLL monitoring, Process monitoring, Windows Registry, Windows event logs

related.Name: APT28
related.Description: APT28 has delivered JHUHUGIT and Koadic by executing PowerShell commands through DDE in Word documents.[16][17][18]

related.Name: APT37
related.Description: APT37 has used Windows DDE for execution of commands and a malicious VBS.[22]

related.Name: Cobalt Group
related.Description: Cobalt Group has sent malicious Word OLE compound documents to victims.[20]

related.Name: FIN7
related.Description: FIN7 spear phishing campaigns have included malicious Word documents with DDE execution.[19]

related.Name: Gallmaker
related.Description: Gallmaker attempted to exploit Microsoft’s DDE protocol in order to gain access to victim machines and for execution.[23]

related.Name: GravityRAT
related.Description: GravityRAT has been delivered via Word documents using DDE for execution.[11]

related.Name: HAWKBALL
related.Description: HAWKBALL has used an OLE object that uses Equation Editor to drop the embedded shellcode.[14]

related.Name: KeyBoy
related.Description: KeyBoy uses the Dynamic Data Exchange (DDE) protocol to download remote payloads.[13]

related.Name: MuddyWater
related.Description: MuddyWater has used malware that can execute PowerShell scripts via DDE.[21]

related.Name: Patchwork
related.Description: Patchwork leveraged the DDE protocol to deliver their malware.[15]

related.Name: POWERSTATS
related.Description: POWERSTATS can use DDE to execute additional payloads on compromised hosts.[12]

related.Name: TA505
related.Description: TA505 has leveraged malicious Word documents that abused DDE.[24]
On Windows 10, enable Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules to prevent DDE attacks and spawning of child processes from Office programs.[9][6]

related.Mitigation: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
related.Description: Registry keys specific to Microsoft Office feature control security can be set to disable automatic DDE/OLE execution. Microsoft also created, and enabled by default, Registry keys to completely disable DDE execution in Word and Excel.[3][1][8][2]
Consider disabling embedded files in Office programs, such as OneNote, that do not work with Protected View.[6][8]
